Executive Summary

Bridgeport Energy LLC

Bridgeport, CT



1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Bridgeport Energy LLC is a natural gas fired electric generating facility.  Aqueous 

ammonia is used for emissions control (NOx).  By virtue of the toxic effects associated 

with ammonia, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions when handling the 

chemical in order to prevent unnecessary human exposure, reduce the threat to personnel 

at Bridgeport Energy, and to reduce the threat to nearby community members.  

Bridgeport Energy is strongly committed to employee and public safety and to the 

environment.  Safety at the facility depends, among other factors, upon the manner in 

which aqueous ammonia is stored and handled.   Equipment design, comprehensive 

operation and response procedures, and periodic training received by plant operators add 

to the inherent safety of ammonia storage and use at the facility.



2.  The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



Aqueous ammonia is the only chemical used or stored at the Bridgeport Energy facility 

that is subject to the Chemical Accident Prevention regulations (40CFR68) because it is 

stored above the threshold amount and concentration.  As such, this Risk Management 

Plan (RMP) only addresses aqueous ammonia.  As part of this RMP, worst case and 

alternative release scenarios have been evaluated and a prevention program developed.  

Complete documentation of the program elements is maintained at the site.



The aqueous ammonia is delivered directly to the ammonia storage tanks.  Access to the 

Bridgeport Energy facility and, therefore, to the tanks is restricted to authorized personnel 

and third-party contractors.



 



3.  The Worst Case Release Scenario and Alternative Release Scenario

 

The worst case release scenario involves the contents of one of the ammonia tanks being 

released under worst case meteorological conditions.  The containm

ent dike around each 

tank is large enough to hold the entire contents of the tank.  In addition, these dikes drain 

to an underground containment pit which greatly reduces the exposed surface area and 

the potential quantity of vapor release.   



The alternative release scenario involves a break in the transfer hose during tank truck 

offloading operations resulting in a release of ammonia to the truck unloading 

containment and the tank containment and pit.  This alternative release scenario does 

consider that this operation is monitored by both the truck driver and plant personnel and 

assumes more realistic meteorological conditions.  



4.  The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical Specific 

Prevention Steps



Bridgeport Energy has taken all of the necessary steps to comply with the accidental 

release prevention requirements set forth in 40CFR68.  The following sections briefly 

describe the release prevention program that is in place at the site:



Safety 

Bridgeport Energy has detailed, written safety procedures which describe the chemical 

hazards, equipment design standards, and operational controls associated with all aspects 

of the ammonia system.



Hazard Review

A process hazards analysis was conducted using the What-If Checklist methodology.  

This analysis focused on operating procedures, equipment design and function, and 

handling practices to identify potential hazards.  The Process Hazard analyses was conducted by qualified 

personnel with extensive knowledge of facility operations.  All findings relative to these analyses were 

addressed in a timely manner.  Additional periodic reviews will be conducted to ensure any hazards 

associated with changes to equipment and/or operating procedures are properly identified and evaluated.  



Operating Procedures

For the purpose of safely conducting activities at the Bridgeport Energy facility, 

including those relating to the storage, handling, and use

of ammonia, Bridgeport Energy 

maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of 

operation such as initial startup, normal operation, temporary operations, emergency 

shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  This 

information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to the operators involved in 

the process.



Training

Bridgeport Energy has a comprehensive training and operator qualification program in 

place to ensure that all employees engaged in the operation of the plant are competent in 

all operating procedures.  New employees receive training and all employees receive 

refresher training at regular intervals.



Maintenance

Bridgeport Energy carries out documented maintenance checks on all plant processes to 

ensure proper functioning.  Maintenance activities are carried out by qualified personnel 

with previous training in these practices.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the 

maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.  



Compliance Audits

Bridgeport Energy conducts routine compliance audits of the ammonia system 

operations in accordance with 40CFR68.  These audits are used to ensure that all 

processes associated with the storage, handling and use of aqueous ammonia is being 

conducted in a manner to ensure the safety of plant personnel and all others who may 

come in contact with the facility. 



Incident Investigation

Bridgeport Energy has an incident investigation program which would be used to fully 

investigate any accidents, injuries and/or close calls associated with the aqueous 

ammonia systems.  Any incidents will be investigated immediately to ascertain the root 

cause and corrective actions required to prevent recurrence.  All incident investigations 

will be documented and the reports maintained at the facility in accordance with records 

retention requirements. 



Five-Year Accident History

There has never

been an accident involving the ammonia at the Bridgeport Energy 

facility.  



Emergency Response Plan

In the event of a release of aqueous ammonia, Bridgeport Energy will immediately 

contact the Bridgeport Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), the local Fire 

Department, and an outside emergency response contractor, who will manage all but 

minor leaks/releases, which will be addressed by plant personnel.  Plant personnel will 

not be actively responding to non-incidental releases of aqueous ammonia.  Bridgeport 

Energy has an Integrated Contingency Plan in place to ensure proper notifications are 

made and safety precautions are taken.
